name: Pectoralis Major
description: Large, fan-shaped muscle that makes up the bulk of the chest wall. Consists of clavicular head (upper chest) and sternal head (lower/mid chest).
function: Horizontal adduction and internal rotation of the shoulder joint. Primary mover in pushing movements.
importance: Essential for pushing strength, protecting the ribcage, and upper body aesthetics.

name: Pectoralis Minor
description: Small, triangular muscle located beneath the pectoralis major, attaching from ribs 3-5 to the scapula.
function: Stabilizes the scapula by drawing it forward and downward against the thoracic wall.
importance: Critical for scapular stability and proper shoulder mechanics. Often tight in those with poor posture.

name: Latissimus Dorsi
description: The widest muscle in the human body, spanning from the lower back to the upper arm. Creates the V-taper appearance.
function: Shoulder extension, adduction, and internal rotation. Primary mover in pulling exercises.
importance: Critical for pulling strength, spinal stability, and protecting the lower back.

name: Trapezius
description: Large, trapezoid-shaped muscle extending from the skull to the mid-back. Has upper, middle, and lower fibers.
function: Upper fibers elevate scapula (shrugging), middle fibers retract scapula, lower fibers depress scapula.
importance: Essential for scapular control, neck stability, and overhead movements. Commonly tight from desk work.

name: Rhomboid Major
description: Diamond-shaped muscle between the spine and scapula, beneath the trapezius.
function: Retracts and elevates the scapula, rotates scapula to depress the glenoid cavity.
importance: Critical for good posture and scapular stability. Weak rhomboids contribute to rounded shoulders.

name: Rhomboid Minor
description: Small muscle superior to the rhomboid major, connecting the spine to the scapula.
function: Works with rhomboid major to retract and stabilize the scapula.
importance: Contributes to scapular control and postural alignment.

name: Deltoid (Anterior)
description: Front portion of the deltoid muscle, originating from the lateral clavicle.
function: Shoulder flexion (raising arm forward), horizontal adduction, and internal rotation.
importance: Primary mover in front raises and assists in all pressing movements.

name: Deltoid (Lateral)
description: Middle portion of the deltoid, originating from the acromion process.
function: Shoulder abduction (raising arm to the side). Primary muscle for shoulder width.
importance: Creates shoulder width and roundness. Essential for lateral raise movements.

name: Deltoid (Posterior)
description: Rear portion of the deltoid, originating from the spine of the scapula.
function: Shoulder extension, horizontal abduction, and external rotation.
importance: Often underdeveloped. Critical for shoulder balance and injury prevention.

name: Supraspinatus
description: Rotator cuff muscle located above the spine of the scapula.
function: Initiates shoulder abduction (first 15 degrees) and stabilizes the humeral head.
importance: Most commonly injured rotator cuff muscle. Critical for overhead movements.

name: Infraspinatus
description: Rotator cuff muscle covering most of the scapula below its spine.
function: External rotation of the shoulder and stabilization of the humeral head.
importance: Essential for throwing motions and shoulder stability during pressing.

name: Teres Minor
description: Small rotator cuff muscle along the lateral border of the scapula.
function: External rotation and adduction of the shoulder, stabilizes humeral head.
importance: Works with infraspinatus for external rotation strength.

name: Teres Major
description: Thick muscle from the lower scapula to the humerus, not part of rotator cuff.
function: Internal rotation, adduction, and extension of the shoulder.
importance: Assists the lats in pulling movements. Sometimes called 'lat's little helper'.

name: Subscapularis
description: Largest rotator cuff muscle, located on the anterior surface of the scapula.
function: Internal rotation of the shoulder and stabilization of the humeral head.
importance: The strongest internal rotator. Critical for shoulder stability in all movements.

name: Serratus Anterior
description: Fan-shaped muscle on the lateral rib cage, with finger-like projections.
function: Protracts scapula (pushes it forward), rotates scapula upward for overhead reach.
importance: Critical for punching power and overhead pressing. Weakness causes scapular winging.

name: Biceps Brachii
description: Two-headed muscle on the front of the upper arm with long and short heads.
function: Elbow flexion and forearm supination. Also assists in shoulder flexion.
importance: Primary elbow flexor. Essential for pulling and lifting tasks.

name: Brachialis
description: Deep muscle beneath the biceps, from mid-humerus to ulna.
function: Pure elbow flexion regardless of forearm position.
importance: Actually stronger than biceps for elbow flexion. Adds arm thickness.

name: Brachioradialis
description: Prominent forearm muscle running from lower humerus to the radius.
function: Elbow flexion, especially with forearm in neutral position.
importance: Major contributor to grip strength and forearm aesthetics.

name: Triceps Brachii (Long Head)
description: The only triceps head that crosses the shoulder joint, originating from the scapula.
function: Elbow extension and shoulder extension/adduction.
importance: Largest triceps head. Best trained with overhead movements.

name: Triceps Brachii (Lateral Head)
description: Outer triceps head originating from the posterior humerus.
function: Elbow extension. Most visible head from the side.
importance: Creates the horseshoe appearance. Activated in all pressing movements.

name: Triceps Brachii (Medial Head)
description: Deep triceps head beneath the long and lateral heads.
function: Elbow extension. Active throughout entire range of motion.
importance: The workhorse of elbow extension, always active during triceps movements.

name: Forearm Flexors
description: Group of muscles on the anterior forearm including flexor carpi radialis, flexor carpi ulnaris, and palmaris longus.
function: Wrist flexion, finger flexion, and grip strength.
importance: Essential for grip strength in all pulling and carrying movements.

name: Forearm Extensors
description: Group of muscles on the posterior forearm including extensor carpi radialis and extensor digitorum.
function: Wrist extension, finger extension, and grip support.
importance: Balance forearm flexors. Weakness contributes to tennis elbow.

name: Rectus Abdominis
description: The 'six-pack' muscle running vertically from pubic bone to sternum, divided by tendinous intersections.
function: Spinal flexion (crunching motion), compression of abdominal contents, forced expiration.
importance: Primary trunk flexor. Important for posture, breathing, and protecting internal organs.

name: External Obliques
description: Largest abdominal muscles on the sides, with fibers running diagonally downward.
function: Trunk rotation (opposite side), lateral flexion, spinal flexion, compression.
importance: Critical for rotational power in sports and protecting the spine during twisting.

name: Internal Obliques
description: Deep abdominal muscles beneath external obliques, fibers run diagonally upward.
function: Trunk rotation (same side), lateral flexion, spinal flexion, compression.
importance: Works with external obliques for powerful rotation and core stability.

name: Transverse Abdominis
description: Deepest abdominal muscle with horizontal fibers wrapping around the trunk like a corset.
function: Compresses abdominal contents, stabilizes spine, forced expiration.
importance: The body's natural weight belt. Critical for spinal stability in all movements.

name: Erector Spinae
description: Group of three muscles (iliocostalis, longissimus, spinalis) running along the spine.
function: Spinal extension, lateral flexion, maintains upright posture.
importance: Primary back extensors. Critical for deadlifts, good posture, and preventing back pain.

name: Multifidus
description: Deep spinal muscles spanning 2-4 vertebrae, running the entire length of the spine.
function: Segmental spinal stabilization and extension.
importance: Critical for spinal stability. Atrophies quickly with back pain, causing ongoing issues.

name: Quadratus Lumborum
description: Deep muscle connecting the pelvis to the lower ribs and lumbar spine.
function: Lateral flexion of spine, hip hiking, stabilizes pelvis and lumbar spine.
importance: Often a source of lower back pain when tight. Important for single-leg stance stability.

name: Diaphragm
description: Dome-shaped muscle separating thoracic and abdominal cavities.
function: Primary breathing muscle. Contracts to create negative pressure for inhalation.
importance: Essential for life. Proper diaphragmatic breathing improves core stability and reduces stress.

name: Psoas Major
description: Deep hip flexor connecting lumbar spine to the femur.
function: Hip flexion, external rotation, lateral flexion of spine.
importance: Only muscle connecting spine to legs. Often tight from sitting, contributing to back pain.

name: Iliacus
description: Fan-shaped muscle lining the inner surface of the ilium (hip bone).
function: Hip flexion and external rotation. Works with psoas as 'iliopsoas'.
importance: Powerful hip flexor. Tightness contributes to anterior pelvic tilt.

name: Gluteus Maximus
description: Largest muscle in the body, forming the bulk of the buttocks.
function: Hip extension, external rotation, abduction (upper fibers), adduction (lower fibers).
importance: Most powerful muscle. Critical for running, jumping, climbing, and preventing knee/back issues.

name: Gluteus Medius
description: Fan-shaped muscle on the outer pelvis, partially covered by gluteus maximus.
function: Hip abduction, internal rotation (anterior fibers), external rotation (posterior fibers).
importance: Critical for single-leg stability. Weakness causes knee valgus and hip drop during walking.

name: Gluteus Minimus
description: Smallest gluteal muscle, located deep to gluteus medius.
function: Hip abduction and internal rotation. Stabilizes pelvis during walking.
importance: Works with gluteus medius for hip stability. Often a source of referred pain.

name: Tensor Fasciae Latae (TFL)
description: Small muscle on the outer hip that connects to the IT band.
function: Hip flexion, abduction, and internal rotation. Tenses the IT band.
importance: Often overactive compensating for weak glutes. Contributes to IT band syndrome.

name: Piriformis
description: Deep hip external rotator beneath the gluteus maximus.
function: External rotation of hip (when extended), abduction (when flexed).
importance: Sciatic nerve runs near or through it. Tightness can cause sciatica-like symptoms.

name: Quadriceps (Rectus Femoris)
description: The only quad muscle crossing both hip and knee joints, running down center of thigh.
function: Knee extension and hip flexion.
importance: Active in kicking motions. Can be strained in explosive movements.

name: Quadriceps (Vastus Lateralis)
description: Largest quad muscle on the outer thigh.
function: Knee extension. Most powerful of the quad muscles.
importance: Creates outer thigh sweep. Common site for intramuscular injections.

name: Quadriceps (Vastus Medialis)
description: Inner quad muscle with prominent 'teardrop' shape near the knee.
function: Knee extension, especially the last 15 degrees. Stabilizes the patella.
importance: Critical for knee health. Weakness contributes to patellar tracking issues.

name: Quadriceps (Vastus Intermedius)
description: Deep quad muscle beneath rectus femoris.
function: Knee extension.
importance: Works throughout entire range of knee extension.

name: Hamstrings (Biceps Femoris)
description: Two-headed hamstring on the outer posterior thigh.
function: Knee flexion, hip extension, external rotation of tibia.
importance: Most commonly strained hamstring. Important for deceleration in sports.

name: Hamstrings (Semitendinosus)
description: Inner hamstring with long tendon, part of the pes anserinus.
function: Knee flexion, hip extension, internal rotation of tibia.
importance: Commonly used for ACL reconstruction grafts.

name: Hamstrings (Semimembranosus)
description: Deep inner hamstring beneath semitendinosus.
function: Knee flexion, hip extension, internal rotation of tibia.
importance: Provides medial knee stability.

name: Adductor Magnus
description: Largest adductor, with two parts: adductor and hamstring portions.
function: Hip adduction, assists in hip extension (hamstring portion) and flexion.
importance: Powerful hip adductor and extensor. Often underutilized in training.

name: Adductor Longus
description: Triangular muscle in the medial thigh, most anterior of adductors.
function: Hip adduction and flexion.
importance: Most commonly strained adductor. Important for lateral movement sports.

name: Adductor Brevis
description: Short adductor muscle deep to adductor longus.
function: Hip adduction and flexion.
importance: Contributes to groin strength and stability.

name: Gracilis
description: Long, thin muscle on the inner thigh, crossing both hip and knee.
function: Hip adduction, hip flexion, knee flexion, internal rotation of tibia.
importance: Part of pes anserinus. Sometimes used for ACL reconstruction.

name: Pectineus
description: Flat muscle at the top of the inner thigh.
function: Hip flexion, adduction, and slight internal rotation.
importance: Assists in hip flexion and adduction movements.

name: Sartorius
description: Longest muscle in the body, crossing from outer hip to inner knee.
function: Hip flexion, abduction, external rotation; knee flexion.
importance: Allows the cross-legged sitting position. Part of pes anserinus.

name: Gastrocnemius
description: Superficial calf muscle with two heads, crossing both knee and ankle.
function: Ankle plantarflexion (pointing toes) and knee flexion.
importance: Primary calf muscle for explosive movements. Creates calf shape.

name: Soleus
description: Deep calf muscle beneath gastrocnemius, crossing only the ankle.
function: Ankle plantarflexion. Primary postural muscle for standing.
importance: Critical for endurance activities. Works constantly when standing.

name: Tibialis Anterior
description: Muscle on the front of the shin.
function: Ankle dorsiflexion (lifting toes) and foot inversion.
importance: Prevents foot drop during walking. Shin splints often involve this muscle.

name: Tibialis Posterior
description: Deep muscle of the posterior lower leg.
function: Ankle plantarflexion and foot inversion. Supports the arch.
importance: Critical for arch support. Dysfunction causes flat feet.

name: Peroneus Longus
description: Lateral lower leg muscle running behind the ankle.
function: Ankle plantarflexion and foot eversion.
importance: Provides lateral ankle stability. Prevents ankle sprains.

name: Peroneus Brevis
description: Shorter lateral lower leg muscle beneath peroneus longus.
function: Ankle plantarflexion and foot eversion.
importance: Works with peroneus longus for ankle stability.

name: Sternocleidomastoid
description: Large neck muscle from sternum and clavicle to mastoid process behind ear.
function: Unilateral: rotates head to opposite side. Bilateral: flexes neck.
importance: Primary neck flexor. Often tight from forward head posture.

name: Scalenes
description: Three muscles (anterior, middle, posterior) on the side of the neck.
function: Lateral neck flexion, assists in breathing by elevating upper ribs.
importance: Accessory breathing muscles. Can compress nerves causing thoracic outlet syndrome.

name: Levator Scapulae
description: Muscle from upper cervical vertebrae to the superior angle of scapula.
function: Elevates scapula, assists in neck lateral flexion and rotation.
importance: Common site of neck/shoulder tension. Often tight from stress and poor posture.

name: Popliteus
description: Small muscle at the back of the knee.
function: Unlocks the knee from full extension, internal rotation of tibia.
importance: Initiates knee flexion from locked position. Important for knee stability.

name: Skull (Cranium)
description: Composed of 22 bones: 8 cranial bones protecting the brain and 14 facial bones.
function: Protects the brain, houses sensory organs, provides attachment for facial muscles.
importance: Essential protection for the brain and sensory organs.

name: Frontal Bone
description: Forms the forehead and upper eye sockets.
function: Protects frontal lobes of brain, forms roof of eye sockets.
importance: Protects the frontal brain and provides forehead structure.

name: Parietal Bones
description: Two bones forming the top and sides of the skull.
function: Protect the parietal lobes of the brain.
importance: Form the main dome of the skull providing brain protection.

name: Temporal Bones
description: Two bones on the sides of the skull housing the ear structures.
function: Protect temporal lobes, house middle and inner ear, form jaw joint.
importance: Critical for hearing and balance. Contains the ear ossicles.

name: Occipital Bone
description: Bone at the back and base of the skull with the foramen magnum.
function: Protects cerebellum and brainstem, allows spinal cord passage.
importance: Contains foramen magnum where spinal cord connects to brain.

name: Sphenoid Bone
description: Butterfly-shaped bone at the base of the skull.
function: Connects to all other cranial bones, houses pituitary gland.
importance: Keystone of cranial floor. Critical for skull structure.

name: Ethmoid Bone
description: Spongy bone between the eyes forming part of nasal cavity.
function: Forms nasal cavity walls, supports olfactory nerves.
importance: Critical for sense of smell and nasal structure.

name: Mandible
description: The lower jaw bone, the only movable skull bone.
function: Enables chewing, speaking, and facial expression.
importance: Only movable skull bone. Essential for eating and speech.

name: Maxilla
description: Two fused bones forming the upper jaw and central face.
function: Holds upper teeth, forms floor of eye sockets and nasal cavity.
importance: Central to facial structure and upper dentition.

name: Cervical Vertebrae (C1-C7)
description: Seven vertebrae of the neck, including atlas (C1) and axis (C2).
function: Support head, protect cervical spinal cord, allow neck movement.
importance: Most mobile spinal region. C1-C2 allow head rotation.

name: Thoracic Vertebrae (T1-T12)
description: Twelve vertebrae of the mid-back, each articulating with a rib pair.
function: Protect thoracic spinal cord, anchor ribs, allow limited rotation.
importance: Attachment point for ribcage. Most stable spinal region.

name: Lumbar Vertebrae (L1-L5)
description: Five large vertebrae of the lower back.
function: Bear most body weight, protect lumbar spinal cord and nerves.
importance: Strongest vertebrae. Common site of back pain and disc issues.

name: Sacrum
description: Five fused vertebrae forming a triangular bone at the base of spine.
function: Connects spine to pelvis, transmits weight to hip bones.
importance: Keystone of pelvis. Critical for weight transfer and stability.

name: Coccyx
description: Three to five fused vertebrae forming the tailbone.
function: Attachment for pelvic floor muscles and ligaments.
importance: Anchor for pelvic floor. Can be painful if injured.

name: Ribs (1-12)
description: Twelve pairs of curved bones forming the ribcage.
function: Protect heart and lungs, assist breathing, provide muscle attachment.
importance: Essential protection for vital organs. Enable breathing mechanics.

name: Sternum
description: Flat bone in the center of the chest (manubrium, body, xiphoid process).
function: Anchors ribs anteriorly, protects heart, attachment for muscles.
importance: Central chest protection. Site for CPR compressions.

name: Clavicle
description: S-shaped bone connecting sternum to scapula (collarbone).
function: Struts shoulder away from body, transmits forces, protects vessels.
importance: Only bony connection between arm and trunk. Commonly fractured.

name: Scapula
description: Triangular flat bone on the upper back (shoulder blade).
function: Provides attachment for 17 muscles, forms shoulder socket.
importance: Platform for shoulder movement. Scapular control is critical for arm function.

name: Humerus
description: Long bone of the upper arm from shoulder to elbow.
function: Forms shoulder and elbow joints, attachment for arm muscles.
importance: Largest arm bone. Enables wide range of upper limb movements.

name: Radius
description: Lateral forearm bone (thumb side), shorter than ulna.
function: Forms wrist joint, allows forearm rotation (pronation/supination).
importance: Critical for wrist mobility and grip function.

name: Ulna
description: Medial forearm bone (pinky side), forms elbow point.
function: Forms elbow joint with humerus, stabilizes forearm.
importance: Primary elbow bone. Olecranon forms the elbow point.

name: Carpal Bones
description: Eight small bones of the wrist arranged in two rows.
function: Allow complex wrist movements, transmit forces from hand to forearm.
importance: Enable the wrist's wide range of motion.

name: Metacarpals
description: Five bones forming the palm of the hand.
function: Form palm structure, connect wrist to fingers.
importance: Foundation of hand grip and fine motor control.

name: Phalanges (Hand)
description: 14 finger bones: 2 in thumb, 3 in each finger.
function: Enable gripping, fine motor skills, touch sensation.
importance: Essential for dexterity and manipulation.

name: Ilium
description: Largest part of hip bone, forming the 'wing' of the pelvis.
function: Provides attachment for gluteal and abdominal muscles.
importance: Major muscle attachment site. Forms sacroiliac joint with sacrum.

name: Ischium
description: Lower back part of hip bone forming the 'sit bones'.
function: Bears weight when sitting, attachment for hamstrings.
importance: Weight-bearing in seated position. Hamstring origin.

name: Pubis
description: Front part of hip bone, meeting at pubic symphysis.
function: Completes pelvic ring, attachment for adductors and abdominals.
importance: Completes anterior pelvis. Site of adductor attachment.

name: Femur
description: Longest, heaviest, and strongest bone in the body (thighbone).
function: Supports body weight, forms hip and knee joints.
importance: Critical for locomotion. Contains largest bone marrow cavity.

name: Patella
description: Sesamoid bone embedded in the quadriceps tendon (kneecap).
function: Protects knee joint, increases quadriceps leverage.
importance: Increases quadriceps efficiency by 30-50%.

name: Tibia
description: Larger lower leg bone (shinbone), bearing body weight.
function: Primary weight-bearing bone of lower leg, forms knee and ankle joints.
importance: Second largest bone. Common site of stress fractures.

name: Fibula
description: Thin lateral lower leg bone, not weight-bearing.
function: Muscle attachment, stabilizes ankle, forms lateral malleolus.
importance: Forms outer ankle bone. Important for ankle stability.

name: Tarsal Bones
description: Seven bones of the ankle and hindfoot including calcaneus and talus.
function: Form ankle joint, support body weight, enable foot movement.
importance: Calcaneus is the largest foot bone. Talus connects to leg.

name: Metatarsals
description: Five long bones forming the middle of the foot.
function: Form arch of foot, provide leverage for push-off.
importance: Critical for walking and running mechanics.

name: Phalanges (Foot)
description: 14 toe bones: 2 in big toe, 3 in each other toe.
function: Balance, push-off during walking, grip surfaces.
importance: Essential for balance and gait.

name: Hyoid Bone
description: U-shaped bone in the neck, not articulating with any other bone.
function: Anchors tongue muscles, supports larynx during swallowing.
importance: Only bone not connected to another bone. Essential for speech.

name: Heart
description: Four-chambered muscular organ, size of a fist, beating ~100,000 times daily.
function: Pumps oxygenated blood to body and deoxygenated blood to lungs.
importance: Essential for life. Cardiovascular fitness directly impacts heart health.

name: Lungs
description: Pair of spongy organs with ~300 million alveoli for gas exchange.
function: Exchange oxygen and carbon dioxide between air and blood.
importance: Essential for respiration. Capacity affects endurance performance.

name: Brain
description: ~3 pounds, 86 billion neurons, consisting of cerebrum, cerebellum, and brainstem.
function: Controls all body functions, consciousness, thought, memory, and movement.
importance: Command center of body. Exercise improves brain health and function.

name: Spinal Cord
description: Bundle of nerves running from brainstem through vertebral column.
function: Transmits signals between brain and body, controls reflexes.
importance: Critical pathway for all voluntary movement and sensation.

name: Liver
description: Largest internal organ (~3 lbs), located in upper right abdomen.
function: Metabolism, detoxification, bile production, protein synthesis, glycogen storage.
importance: Essential for metabolism. Processes all absorbed nutrients.

name: Stomach
description: J-shaped muscular organ between esophagus and small intestine.
function: Stores food, secretes acid and enzymes, mechanically breaks down food.
importance: Initiates protein digestion. Capacity ~1 liter.

name: Small Intestine
description: ~20 feet long tube (duodenum, jejunum, ileum) with huge surface area.
function: Primary site of nutrient absorption, continues digestion.
importance: Absorbs 90% of nutrients. Surface area of a tennis court.

name: Large Intestine
description: ~5 feet long tube (cecum, colon, rectum) framing the small intestine.
function: Absorbs water and electrolytes, forms and stores feces, houses gut bacteria.
importance: Home to gut microbiome. Critical for immune function.

name: Pancreas
description: Elongated gland behind the stomach, ~6 inches long.
function: Produces digestive enzymes and hormones (insulin, glucagon).
importance: Critical for blood sugar regulation and digestion.

name: Gallbladder
description: Small pear-shaped sac beneath the liver.
function: Stores and concentrates bile for fat digestion.
importance: Aids fat digestion. Can be removed without major consequences.

name: Kidneys
description: Two bean-shaped organs (~5 inches) filtering blood.
function: Filter blood, remove waste, regulate fluid/electrolyte balance, produce hormones.
importance: Filter 180 liters of blood daily. Critical for homeostasis.

name: Bladder
description: Muscular sac in the pelvis storing urine.
function: Stores urine until voluntary release, can hold ~500ml.
importance: Allows controlled urination. Capacity varies with training.

name: Spleen
description: Fist-sized organ in upper left abdomen.
function: Filters blood, recycles old red blood cells, stores platelets, immune function.
importance: Largest lymphoid organ. Important for immunity.

name: Thyroid Gland
description: Butterfly-shaped gland in the front of the neck.
function: Produces hormones regulating metabolism, growth, and development.
importance: Controls metabolic rate. Dysfunction affects energy and weight.

name: Adrenal Glands
description: Two small glands sitting atop each kidney.
function: Produce cortisol, adrenaline, aldosterone, and some sex hormones.
importance: Critical for stress response and metabolism.

name: Skin
description: Largest organ (~20 sq ft), three layers: epidermis, dermis, hypodermis.
function: Protection, temperature regulation, sensation, vitamin D synthesis.
importance: First line of defense. Prevents dehydration and infection.

name: Eyes
description: Paired organs of vision, ~1 inch diameter.
function: Detect light and convert to electrical signals for the brain.
importance: Primary sense organ. Provides 80% of sensory information.

name: Ears
description: Organs of hearing and balance with outer, middle, and inner sections.
function: Detect sound waves and head position/movement for balance.
importance: Essential for hearing and equilibrium.

name: Aorta
description: Largest artery in the body, arising from the left ventricle.
function: Distributes oxygenated blood to all body tissues via branching arteries.
importance: Main highway of arterial blood. Aortic health is critical.

name: Superior Vena Cava
description: Large vein returning blood from upper body to right atrium.
function: Returns deoxygenated blood from head, arms, and upper torso to heart.
importance: Major venous return pathway from upper body.

name: Inferior Vena Cava
description: Largest vein, returning blood from lower body to right atrium.
function: Returns deoxygenated blood from abdomen, pelvis, and legs to heart.
importance: Major venous return from lower body. Runs through diaphragm.

name: Pulmonary Arteries
description: Arteries carrying deoxygenated blood from right ventricle to lungs.
function: Transport blood to lungs for oxygenation.
importance: Only arteries carrying deoxygenated blood.

name: Pulmonary Veins
description: Four veins carrying oxygenated blood from lungs to left atrium.
function: Return oxygen-rich blood from lungs to heart for distribution.
importance: Only veins carrying oxygenated blood.

name: Carotid Arteries
description: Major arteries on each side of the neck supplying the head.
function: Supply oxygenated blood to brain, face, and neck.
importance: Critical brain blood supply. Carotid pulse easily palpated.

name: Jugular Veins
description: Major veins draining blood from the head and brain.
function: Return deoxygenated blood from head to superior vena cava.
importance: Primary venous drainage of brain. Visible in neck.

name: Subclavian Arteries/Veins
description: Major vessels beneath the clavicle supplying the arms.
function: Supply and drain blood from upper limbs.
importance: Main blood supply to arms. Used for central line access.

name: Brachial Artery
description: Main artery of the upper arm, continuation of axillary artery.
function: Supplies blood to arm. Used for blood pressure measurement.
importance: Site for BP reading. Divides into radial and ulnar arteries.

name: Radial Artery
description: Artery on the thumb side of the forearm.
function: Supplies lateral forearm and hand. Pulse easily felt at wrist.
importance: Most common pulse site. Used for arterial blood draws.

name: Femoral Artery/Vein
description: Major vessels of the thigh, passing through femoral triangle.
function: Supply and drain blood from lower limbs.
importance: Main blood supply to leg. Pulse palpable at groin.

name: Popliteal Artery/Vein
description: Major vessels behind the knee.
function: Continue blood supply to lower leg. Vulnerable position behind knee.
importance: Pulse checked behind knee. Important for leg circulation.

name: Tibial Arteries
description: Anterior and posterior tibial arteries supplying the lower leg and foot.
function: Supply blood to shin, calf, ankle, and foot.
importance: Posterior tibial pulse felt behind medial malleolus.

name: Great Saphenous Vein
description: Longest vein in body, running from foot to femoral vein.
function: Drains superficial leg tissues. Common site for varicose veins.
importance: Used for bypass grafts. Common varicose vein site.

name: Portal Vein
description: Large vein carrying blood from digestive organs to liver.
function: Delivers nutrient-rich blood from gut to liver for processing.
importance: Unique venous system. All absorbed nutrients pass through liver first.

name: Coronary Arteries
description: Arteries supplying blood to the heart muscle itself.
function: Deliver oxygen and nutrients to myocardium.
importance: Blockage causes heart attack. Target of bypass surgery.

name: Sciatic Nerve
description: Largest nerve in body, running from lower back through buttock and down leg.
function: Provides motor and sensory function to posterior thigh and entire lower leg.
importance: Sciatica is compression of this nerve. Critical for leg function.

name: Femoral Nerve
description: Major nerve of the anterior thigh from lumbar plexus.
function: Controls quadriceps, sensation to anterior thigh and medial leg.
importance: Essential for knee extension and walking.

name: Brachial Plexus
description: Network of nerves from C5-T1 supplying the upper limb.
function: Provides all motor and sensory innervation to arm and hand.
importance: Injury causes significant arm dysfunction. Stingers in sports.

name: Median Nerve
description: Major nerve running down center of arm to hand.
function: Controls forearm flexors, thumb muscles, sensation to lateral palm.
importance: Compressed in carpal tunnel syndrome. Essential for grip.

name: Ulnar Nerve
description: Nerve running along medial arm, passing behind elbow.
function: Controls intrinsic hand muscles, sensation to medial hand.
importance: 'Funny bone' nerve. Critical for fine hand movements.

name: Radial Nerve
description: Nerve wrapping around humerus, supplying posterior arm.
function: Controls triceps, wrist/finger extensors, sensation to posterior arm/hand.
importance: Vulnerable at spiral groove. Injury causes wrist drop.

name: Vagus Nerve
description: Longest cranial nerve (CN X), running from brainstem to abdomen.
function: Controls heart rate, digestion, immune response, mood regulation.
importance: Key parasympathetic nerve. Vagal tone affects stress response.

name: Phrenic Nerve
description: Nerve from C3-C5 innervating the diaphragm.
function: Controls diaphragm contraction for breathing.
importance: Essential for life. 'C3, 4, 5 keeps the diaphragm alive.'

name: Tibial Nerve
description: Branch of sciatic nerve supplying posterior leg and foot sole.
function: Controls calf muscles, sensation to sole of foot.
importance: Tarsal tunnel syndrome involves this nerve.

name: Common Peroneal Nerve
description: Branch of sciatic nerve wrapping around fibular head.
function: Controls ankle dorsiflexion and foot eversion, sensation to lateral leg.
importance: Vulnerable at fibular head. Injury causes foot drop.

name: Obturator Nerve
description: Nerve from lumbar plexus passing through obturator foramen.
function: Controls adductor muscles, sensation to medial thigh.
importance: Important for hip adduction and stability.

name: Intercostal Nerves
description: Twelve pairs of nerves running between the ribs.
function: Control intercostal muscles, sensation to chest and abdominal wall.
importance: Essential for breathing mechanics. Source of rib pain.

name: Facial Nerve (CN VII)
description: Cranial nerve controlling facial expression muscles.
function: Controls facial expression, taste (anterior 2/3 tongue), tear/saliva production.
importance: Bell's palsy is paralysis of this nerve.

name: Trigeminal Nerve (CN V)
description: Largest cranial nerve with three branches for face sensation and chewing.
function: Facial sensation, controls chewing muscles.
importance: Trigeminal neuralgia causes severe facial pain.

name: Optic Nerve (CN II)
description: Sensory nerve transmitting visual information from retina to brain.
function: Carries visual signals from eye to brain for processing.
importance: Damage causes vision loss. Part of the central nervous system.
